issues.title: Latest version being installed (1.1.5-1~build1) on server and (1.3.3-1+ubuntu16.04+deb.sury.org+1) on local machine
issues.body:
Ran following on both server and local machine:
```
sudo apt-get update
sudp  apt-get install php-mongodb
```
Both machine run php7 on ubuntu 16.04.
Version getting installed is (1.1.5-1~build1) on server and (1.3.3-1+ubuntu16.04+deb.sury.org+1) on my local machine.

Output of
```
$ php -i | grep -E 'mongodb|libmongoc|libbson'
```
**On Local**: 
```
PHP Warning:  Module 'mongodb' already loaded in Unknown on line 0
/etc/php/7.0/cli/conf.d/20-mongodb.ini,
mongodb
libbson bundled version => 1.8.2
libmongoc bundled version => 1.8.2
libmongoc SSL => enabled
libmongoc SSL library => OpenSSL
libmongoc crypto => enabled
libmongoc crypto library => libcrypto
libmongoc crypto system profile => disabled
libmongoc SASL => enabled
mongodb.debug => no value => no value
```
**On Server**:
```
/etc/php/7.0/cli/conf.d/20-mongodb.ini,
mongodb
mongodb support => enabled
mongodb version => 1.1.5
mongodb stability => stable
libmongoc version => 1.3.3
libbson version => 1.3.3
mongodb.debug => no value => no value

```
Running php -m output

**On Local**

```
PHP Warning:  Module 'mongodb' already loaded in Unknown on line 0
[PHP Modules]
calendar
Core

xsl
Zend OPcache
zlib

[Zend Modules]
Zend OPcache
```
**On Server**
```
[PHP Modules]
calendar
Core
ctype
curl
date
dom
exif
fileinfo
filter
ftp
gettext
hash
iconv
json
libxml
mongodb
mysqli
mysqlnd
openssl
pcntl
pcre
PDO
pdo_mysql
Phar
posix
readline
Reflection
session
shmop
SimpleXML
sockets
SPL
standard
sysvmsg
sysvsem
sysvshm
tokenizer
wddx
xml
xmlreader
xmlwriter
xsl
Zend OPcache
zlib

[Zend Modules]
Zend OPcache
```
Tried using the pecl installation way on the server `sudo pecl install mongodb` (after doing a sudo apt-get remove mongodb) The installation completed with  version 1.3.4 getting installed. I added `extension=mongodb.so` to my `/etc/php/7.0/apache2/php.ini` file too. But this doesn't work - 1. php -m didn't have mongodb in the list., 2. Also, running composer update on my php project failed with following output - 

```
Problem 1
    - Installation request for mongodb/mongodb ^1.2 -> satisfiable by mongodb/mongodb[1.2.0].
    - mongodb/mongodb 1.2.0 requires ext-mongodb ^1.3.0 -> the requested PHP extension mongodb has the wrong version (1.1.5) installed.

  To enable extensions, verify that they are enabled in your .ini files:
    - /etc/php/7.0/cli/php.ini

issues.title: php mongodb connect pool
issues.body:
doc ： https://github.com/mongodb/mongo-php-driver/issues
```
For details on supported options, see
 » Connection String Options in the MongoDB manual. 
» Connection pool options are not supported, as the PHP driver does not implement connection pools.
```

mongodb doc: https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/reference/connection-string/#connection-pool-options

ask:

1. php mongodb default connection pool is 100, or 1 ？

2. How do I implement a connection pool in php?

issues.title: php71 mongoDB ext crashing php
issues.body:
### Description

I have created an issue: https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-php/issues/4607 . Andreas told me to create new issue here, since it doesn't seem to be a problem specific to homebrew.

After I install php71-mongodb my php stop working.

I have installed on clean system (High Sierra) php71 with necessary extensions. When I install mongoDB my php stop working. In system.log I see segmentation errors. When I uninstall mongoDB php ext. everything is working correctly.

```

### Environment

issues.title: PHP 7.1 (VC14) mongodb php drive 1.3.x issue
issues.body:
### Description

I'm trying to install `mongodb php drive 1.3.3` with PHP 7.1 (VC14) ts x86
I've tried lots of version, the only version that worked to me is 1.3.0, the later versions didn't work well

### Environment

PHP Version: 7.1.11 ThreadSafe x86
OS: Windows 10
Apache Version: 2.4.29
Working Version: https://pecl.php.net/package/mongodb/1.3.0/windows
Not Working Versions: Newer than 1.3.0


### More details

If I try to use newer version than 1.3.0, the mongodb is not loaded and the following warning is logged to apache:
```
PHP Warning:  PHP Startup: Unable to load dynamic library 'C:\\Apache24\\PHP\\ext\\php_mongodb.dll' - The specified module could not be found.\r\n in Unknown on line 0
```

but if I try with 1.3.0, the mongodb php driver works well

**Note**
Of course I'm choosing **x86 ts** from the mongodb download page

> and even If I try nts or x64, the module will not load, and other message is logged to apache telling that I'm trying wrong version

issues.title: How to build with 32-bit compatibility??
issues.body:
In my linux pc I have already installed `lampp`. So when I build `mongodb.so` using [this](http://php.net/manual/en/mongodb.installation.manual.php) instructions, lampp suddenly says 

> "XAMPP is currently only availably as 32 bit application. Please use a 32 bit compatibility library for your system"

Can anyone help me to build this with 32-bit compatibility as it suggests??

issues.title: BC break: Detected unsupported BSON type 0x06 (undefined)
issues.body:
### Description

Seems like if any value in a document is `undefined`, an exception is thrown since version 1.3+

After upgrading to mongo-php-driver 1.3+, we started getting the error message in the title. I believe this is a big BC break that wasn't clearly warned about in the changelog.
It is common to mistakenly get `undefined` into a value in MongoDB by accident through a badly written JS migration script, and it's not like MongoDB can be told to never store `undefined`. 
Probably caused by:
#545
[PHPC-302](https://jira.mongodb.org/browse/PHPC-302) 
https://jira.mongodb.org/secure/ReleaseNote.jspa?projectId=12484&version=17597

### Version

1.3.0

The version we used before was 1.2.9 which didn't have this issue.

### Environment

CentOS

### Expected and Actual Behavior

Expected: undefined works as normal, being treated as NULL in PHP

Actual: exception being thrown: "Detected unsupported BSON type 0x06"

issues.title: No suitable server found
issues.body:
I am not getting this error all of the times, but sometimes when I open the browser and hit the website, It throws the `No suitable servers found` error, I am using mongodb atlas cloud, and I'm also using that cluster in python. There's no issue with python, but with php (`jenssegers/laravel-mongodb`), I receive the same error sometimes and after reloading 2-3 times, the error doesn't appear, can anybody help me with that?

Here's how my database.php file looks like:

```php
return [
    'default' => env('DB_CONNECTION', 'mongodb'),
    'connections' => [
        'mongodb' => [
            'driver'   => 'mongodb',
            'dsn'      => 'mongodb://'.env('DB_HOST'),
            'database' => env('DB_DATABASE'),
            'username' => env('DB_USERNAME'),
            'password' => env('DB_PASSWORD'),
            'options'  => [
                'database'      => env('DB_AUTH_SOURCE', env('DB_DATABASE')),
                'replicaSet'    => env('DB_REPLICASET'),
                'ssl'           => env('DB_SSL'),
                'maxIdleTimeMS' => 2000
            ]
        ],
    ]
];
```

issues.title: \MongoDB\BSON\UTCDateTime issue
issues.body:
### Description

Briefly describe the issue. Feel free to cross-reference your report with
another related GitHub or JIRA issue for additional context.

Before reporting an issue, check that you are using the most recent version of
the extension.

All BSON\UTCDateTime implimentations are returning MongoDB\Driver\Exception\UnexpectedValueException: Got unsupported type 0 'unknown' when i attempt to insert or update any records in a collection

I was previously using 1.2.9 of the mongodb.dll and installed the latest 1.3.0beta1 release a few days ago with the same result

```
 $write = new \MongoDB\Driver\BulkWrite;
$write->insert($document); //This is where the error is thrown
document object is as follows
object(Project)#3 (8) {
  ["projectName"]=>
  string(39) "Create Project after changing constants"
  ["description"]=>
  string(574) "Lorem Ipsum is simply dummy text of the printing and typesetting industry. Lorem Ipsum has been the industry's standard dummy text ever since the 1500s, when an unknown printer took a galley of type and scrambled it to make a type specimen book. It has survived not only five centuries, but also the leap into electronic typesetting, remaining essentially unchanged. It was popularised in the 1960s with the release of Letraset sheets containing Lorem Ipsum passages, and more recently with desktop publishing software like Aldus PageMaker including versions of Lorem Ipsum."
  ["startDate"]=>
  object(MongoDB\BSON\UTCDateTime)#6 (1) {
    ["milliseconds"]=>
    string(13) "1503002896000"
  }
  ["lastModifiedDate"]=>
  object(MongoDB\BSON\UTCDateTime)#5 (1) {
    ["milliseconds"]=>
    string(13) "1503002896000"
  }
  ["createdBy"]=>
  object(stdClass)#4 (4) {
    ["id"]=>
    string(24) "5824b9f2d4ff1a0fc088b11d"
    ["name"]=>
    string(10) "Deryk King"
    ["email"]=>
    string(22) "deryk.king@brafton.com"
    ["userIcon"]=>
    string(59) "https://avatars3.githubusercontent.com/u/10117938?v=3&s=460"
  }
  ["subject"]=>
  string(13) "Site Redesign"
  ["projectType"]=>
  string(8) "Personal"
  ["status"]=>
  string(4) "open"
}
```

the fields causing the issue are the UTCDateTime fields (startDate, and lastModifiedDate) removing these results in successful insertion.

This does not throw an error on php5.6.23 current phpinfo dump below

### Test Script

If possible, attach a complete PHP script that can be excuted on its own to
reproduce the issue. Clarify whether this script can be run from the CLI or if
it can only be reproduced through a web SAPI.

```
<?php

// TEST SCRIPT
```

If the error only presents itself in a web SAPI, report whether the issue can be
reproduced with PHP's built-in web server, which may be launched with
`php -S localhost:8000`. If not, please note your web server version in the
environment section.

http://php.net/manual/en/features.commandline.webserver.php

### Expected and Actual Behavior
expected behavior is a successful insertion of the document.

How did the script fail to perform the expected task? Feel free to include debug
and/or `var_dump()` output.

If the observed behavior is an unexpected exception, please include its full
message and a backtrace (if relevant). If you encountered a segmentation fault,
please include a GDB backtrace.

https://bugs.php.net/bugs-generating-backtrace.php

```
DEBUG OR BACKTRACE

### Debug Log

If the issue relates to internal driver behavior (e.g. connection issues),
please include a debug log. This may be generated by setting the `mongodb.debug`
INI option to "stderr" or a directory (useful for web SAPIs).

http://php.net/manual/en/mongodb.configuration.php#ini.mongodb.debug

```
DEBUG LOG
```

issues.title: How to suppress the mongodb output?
issues.body:
I am using mongodb-php-driver for my website.  
When my website connected to the mongodb server, I got a number of information related to the mongodb, such as

MongoDB\Database Object ( [databaseName] => db [manager] => MongoDB\Driver\Manager Object ( [uri] => mongodb://localhost:27017 [cluster] => Array ( [0] => Array ( [host] => localhost [port] => 27017 [type] => 1 [is_primary] => [is_secondary] => [is_arbiter] => [is_hidden] => [is_passive] => [last_is_master] => Array ( [ismaster] => 1 [maxBsonObjectSize] => 16777216 [maxMessageSizeBytes] => 48000000 [maxWriteBatchSize] => 1000 [localTime] => MongoDB\BSON\UTCDateTime Object ( [milliseconds] => 1502041102962 ) [maxWireVersion] => 5 [minWireVersion] => 0 [readOnly] => [ok] => 1 ) [round_trip_time] => 88 ) ) ) [readConcern] => MongoDB\Driver\ReadConcern Object ( ) [readPreference] => MongoDB\Driver\ReadPreference Object ( [mode] => primary ) [typeMap] => Array ( [array] => MongoDB\Model\BSONArray [document] => MongoDB\Model\BSONDocument [root] => MongoDB\Model\BSONDocument ) [writeConcern] => MongoDB\Driver\WriteConcern Object ( [j] => ) )

How can I suppress those output, so I can get a clean website?

Thanks

issues.title: OpenSSL version >= 1.1 is not supported

### Description

checking for pkg-config... /usr/bin/pkg-config
configure: error: OpenSSL version >= 1.1 is not supported.

### Environment
Ubuntu 16.04 
OpenSSL 1.1.0f  25 May 2017

/etc/php/7.0/cli/conf.d/20-mongodb.ini,
mongodb
mongodb support => enabled
mongodb version => 1.1.5
mongodb stability => stable
libmongoc version => 1.3.3
libbson version => 1.3.3
mongodb.debug => no value => no value

issues.title: Segmentation fault after connecting to master with long hostnames
issues.body:
### Description

We encountered a segmentation fault while creating a new MongoDB cluster on Google Container Engine. An identical cluster (with minor differences in URLs) works perfectly fine. The error occurs while parsing the response from the initial `isMaster` call and ends with the following error message:

```
mongoc: WARNING > Failed to parse uri for production-mongodb-cluster-1-vm.c.seismic-lexicon-136408.internal:27017
```

A full debug log is included below. Shortening the name from 72 characters to 61 characters fixes the error, is there a hostname length limitation we're not aware of?

### Environment

* MongoDB 3.4.4
* PHP 7.1.4
* ext-mongodb 1.2.8
* libmongoc 1.5.5

[27-Jan-2016 01:35:47] NOTICE: configuration file /etc/php5/fpm/php-fpm.conf test is successful

Exit status: 139

```
Backtrace:
php5-fpm[0x6dee88]

If I remove package libsasl2-dev before compiling, it works fine.

commits.message:
Use AC_HELP_STRING for PHP_ARG_WITH in config.m4

This also documents "yes" values for the libbson/libmongoc parameters, and the "auto" default for SASL.
Document "no" defaults for PHP_ARG_ENABLE flags in config.m4
PHPC-1003: Use container environment for Travis builds

Remove macOS environments from build matrix

Travis' backlog for macOS builds is quite high, and the environments also do not support MongoDB. We can revisit adding these environments down the line when the infrastructure has improved and we sort out explicit installation of MongoDB versions (see: PHPLIB-299).

Note: a macOS build with Secure Channel was manually tested in mongodb/mongo-php-driver#736.

Upgrading run-tests.php is no longer necessary

PHP 5.4 was the last version where run-tests.php failed to report a non-zero exit code after a failure. Since the extension requires 5.5+, we can rely on any existing run-tests.php file.
Add macOS environments to build matrix
Make core and diff debugging more portable

Coveralls API token is not needed for public projects

This was last updated in 90a64b43c9ad8e9e8f297f6f937f9e450ac57ffb when the project was hosted in the 10gen-labs groups.
LibreSSL cannot extract username subject from X509 certs

Do not ignore files within .travis.scripts/

If a directory is excluded, a negation on the files within it (e.g. "!dir/*") has no effect. Since .travis.scripts/ is excluded by ".*", we need to negate the directory itself to ensure the files within are tracked.

Remove old Mongo Orchestration artifacts

These lines were originally added before 1.0 when a local Mongo Orchestration process was used to create the test environments (see: PHPC-128).

Remove old API key for Coveralls

This was originally added in dcd732c485a97c76edaec0e2d7290d3560676d82 and should have been removed when @bjori's coverity hook was removed in 5309c172820df3f08982fd7061704496eae3aad7.
PHPC-888: Support additional TLS libraries for bundled libmongoc

Use single equal sign for test comparisons

The double equal operator is a Bash-specific alias
Fix conditional for whether extension is enabled
PHPC-1098: Use exactly representable floats in tests
PHPC-1096: Allow building with libmongoc's bundled zlib
Only include snappy/zlib checks for bundled libmongoc

PHPC-1092: Don't reset hash on successive get_properties calls

This removes a call to zend_hash_clean() on successive calls to a BSON object's get_properties handler, which can lead to an infinite loop when iterating the object's properties with foreach on PHP 7.x.

For historical reference, the original call to zend_hash_clean() was introduced in ad1f3f049f5c101a8b4f89f13e6384bbefb6ef6c for #607 (PHPC-939).
Add REPLICASET_DNS to basic.inc servers array

Upgrade VM to trusty64 and revise mo installation

This also removes unused server versions.
Add missing json MO config to PECL package
PHPC-1050: Command cursor should not invoke getMore at execution
NOP if xargs input is empty
Ensure pruned utils directory is excluded from find output
Remove XFAIL tests depending on PHPC-1066

Update Makefile target for cleaning test dirs

This prunes the utils directory instead of depending on a whitelist, which would need to be more frequently updated.
PHPC-987: Additional causal consistency spec tests
Update reference to libmongoc in error message
PHPC-1037: Define new constants in config.w32
Regression test for empty command segfault (CDRIVER-2431)
PHPC-1037: Bump libbson and libmongoc to 1.9.0
PHPC-980: Skip session spec test on Travis (pending 3.6)
PHPC-987: Add operation time to Session

PHPC-986: APM-based tests for retryable writes

PHPC did not require any code changes to support retryable writes, as existing URI option processing allows enabling of retryable writes in libmongoc. These tests utilize APM to assert that certain commands include or exclude a transaction ID.
PHPC-980: Use correct topology constant in CLEANUP()

Use uint32_t for server_id args and struct fields

Since Manager methods no longer pass -1 to execute functions in php_phongo.c, server_id should always be unsigned.

PHPC-1066: XFAIL tests for unknown options to execute methods

These tests were extracted from previous tests that combined invalid/unknown options.

PHPC-1057: Refactor option parsing for execute methods

Execute options are now parsed via php_array functions, which makes the options case-sensitive.

A helper function is now used to convert legacy options for the original three execute methods into an array. This simplifies option parsing in php_phongo.c.

Additionally, Manager methods now perform their own server selection, which means that execute functions in php_phongo.c can rely on a server_id being provided.

Tests have been updated to expect a serverId option when relevant (e.g. query opts). Additionally, error tests for execute methods have been improved so that invalid values for all known options are tested.

PHPC-980: MongoDB\Driver\Session and "session" option

This introduces a Session class, which wraps libmongoc's client session object. Additionally, we support a "session" option on Manager and Server execute methods to allow operations to be associated with an explicit session (mostly relevant for causal consistency).

PHPC-1071: Report class name for unexpected object values

This only updates exceptions where object types are entirely unexpected. For instance, options that expect a BSON document (i.e. array or object) need not use this macro, as any object would be accepted.
PHPC-1070: Macro for accessing zval class or type name

PHPC-1072: mongoc_client_command_with_opts() reply must always be freed

Previously, reply might leak if phongo_execute_command() returned due to an error (result=false).
Fix expected output for Server::executeCommand() test
PHPC-834: Process readPreference for executeCommand() on PHP 5.x

Test MONGOC_CMD_RAW options for Server::executeCommand()

This test is adapted from manager-executeCommand-004.phpt.

Note MONGOC_CMD_RAW in executeCommand() option tests

This serves as a reminder that executeCommand() is the execution method for raw commands.

Update APM test for libmongoc CRUD changes

As of mongodb/mongo-c-driver@c2639c821d3c84745bf2dca5629959926a69e973, libmongoc no longer adds a default write concern to commands.

Update tests for invalid BSON in bulk writes

The error message was changed in mongodb/mongo-c-driver@0c9cc9d26728d3cf4dd84e1fe91e75ca40e9a7fd

Update tests for unsupported URI option values

The error message was changed in mongodb/mongo-c-driver@a625b39a2ef868c879b9a6b5eacd2697ddc9a772
Replace tabs with spaces in test files
PHPC-1037: Bump libbson to 1.9.0-rc1 and libmongoc to 1.9.0-dev
Reload VM and restart MO in make test-bootstrap
Remove traces of deprecated nohttpinterface CLI opt

Remove nohttpinterface from replicaset-dns MO configs

This option is no longer supported in 3.6 (see: #687)

nohttpinterface is not supported by mongod 3.6

3.6 is the first and default release version in the MO config and specifying an unsupported command line options prevents the replicaset configuration from starting (in turn, start-servers.php fails).
Fix typo in PECL package description
PHPC-1045: Regression test for SCRAM-SHA-1 auth segfault
PHPC-1044: Bump libbson and libmongoc to 1.8.2
PHPC-1046: Use authSource URI option to specify $external
PHPC-1014: Bump libbson and libmongoc to 1.8.1
Add trailing backslash to last entry in PHP_MONGODB_SOURCES
Use dnl instead of # for internal comments
PHPC-996: Bump min PHP requirement in package.xml to 5.5
PHPC-1007: Bump libbson and libmongoc pkg-config dep to 1.8.0
PHPC-1007: Bump libbson and libmongoc to 1.8.0

PHPC-1008: Use SETUP_OPENSSL() in config.w32 if available

This adds support for OpenSSL 1.1.x when building for PHP 7.1.2+.

Previously, we did not specify a custom path_to_check for crypt32.lib (see 912987c37dc6689d5e27ab4e05c5241d29dc473f); however, SETUP_OPENSSL() does this for OpenSSL 1.0.x and lower, so we can add it back for consistency.
Test against PHP 7.2 on Travis CI
PHPC-1006: Fix test name and add extra regression test
PHPC-1006: Do not modify Persistable::bsonSerialize() retval

PHPC-1005: Use convert_to_object() to create stdClass from array

This will ensure that the array symtable is properly converted to an object proptable in PHP 7.2 (e.g. integer key 0 converts to string key "0").
PHPC-1006: Do not modify Persistable::bsonSerialize() retval

PHPC-1005: Use convert_to_object() to create stdClass from array

This will ensure that the array symtable is properly converted to an object proptable in PHP 7.2 (e.g. integer key 0 converts to string key "0").
Rely on Travis CI to provide MongoDB 3.2

Revert "Use canonical ObjectID class name in tests"

This reverts commit 991cbe887e120b0b2975dc3ffee6c29c702e1596.

Revert "PHPC-1004: Rename CursorId to CursorID"

This reverts commit 708c2140347b6d4888eefd551c84d39f920afeab.
Use canonical ObjectID class name in tests
PHPC-1001: Report field name for invalid UTF-8 and unsupported zval types
PHPC-976: Add more test cases for default read and write concerns
PHPC-976: RC and WC isDefault() tests don't need a server
Ensure date.timezone is defined for UTCDateTimeInterface test

PHPC-994: Assume socklen_t is defined on Windows

This fixes macro redefinition warnings for HAVE_SOCKLEN_T, which were caused by CHECK_FUNC_IN_HEADER() injecting a definition. We can safely assume that Windows builds environments for PHP have socklen_t defined (as does libmongoc in its cmake config).
PHPC-349 and PHPC-981: Fix package builds for APM
PHPC-992: Rename extended JSON functions to[Canonical|Relaxed]ExtendedJSON()
toPHP() error test should not require servers
PHPC-977: Bump libbson and libmongoc to 1.7.0

PHPC-887: Throw for unexpected types in URI options array

Note: generic boolean options (e.g. "ssl") will continue to accept non-boolean types for BC, since we cast via bson_iter_as_bool(). However, RP and WC-specific boolean options (e.g. "slaveOk", "journal") will throw since they previously silently ignored non-boolean values.

In addition to revising read preference tests, this adds new tests for read concern and write concern options.
Regression test for out of range maxStalenessSeconds option in URI string
PHPC-846: Throw if maxStalenessSeconds URI option is out of range

[WIP] PHPC-702: Rely on libbson and libmongoc configure scripts

issue_comments.body:
I suppose one thing that I didn't explain in IRC, but might put the current API in context: the goal of this project is to create a core driver with a bare minimum API with essential features (we only have query, command, and write operations), but keep it flexible enough so that we can implement our current or new API entirely in userland PHP.

Keeping this core API very slim also means it's less work to port over to HHVM or reimplement in PHP (for a mongofill project), and still have the userland APIs work interchangeably with any core implementation.

> In a query all the params are optional, why make all the params mandatory?

In hindsight, I suppose only `$query` is actually required and the subsequent arguments can default to `array()` and `0`, respectively. I believe all of our value objects in the Query, Write, and Command namespaces require all constructor arguments, since the userland API can afford to be explicit when constructing Query and decide to make things optional on its own.

Regarding `$query`, this will include [query modifiers](http://docs.mongodb.org/manual/reference/operator/query-modifier/#operators) at the top level, so a general query for all documents is actually `{ $query: { } }`, not `{ }`.

> How access to the stored values?

The `executeQuery()` methods on Manager and Server would deal with this. There should be no reason for userland code to access the values.

> Maybe fluent? Maybe defensive programming on setters?

Query is an immutable value object. This should be the last step before actually executing a query. In practice, we can easily have userland APIs that look like the current driver or a fluent query builder, which ultimately create this Query object before shipping it across the wire. What we have here is basically the components of an [OP_QUERY](http://docs.mongodb.org/meta-driver/latest/legacy/mongodb-wire-protocol/#op-query) wire protocol message.

> Missing sort and hint params. Why?

These are actually part of the `$query` argument, as [`$hint`](http://docs.mongodb.org/manual/reference/operator/meta/hint/#op._S_hint) and [`$orderby`](http://docs.mongodb.org/manual/reference/operator/meta/orderby/#op._S_orderby) keys. See above.

> Why final classes? Maybe someone needs extend it.

We declared private properties just to conceptualize before implementing in C, but these will likely be internal properties (not private or any other visibility).

This is an opinionated stance, but users should use composition instead of extension. That has been one of the headaches of the current driver, which was doublly bad because the C code was actually invoking PHP methods (something that is still being refactored as we get the chance).

Also, we're starting with final for as many classes as possible and may then decide to open them up. We can always remove `final` and preserve BC, but we can't do the reverse. So, this is a bit similar to the other OO adage of making everything private at first and carefully deciding what needs to be accessible later on.

> Why accept arrays or object?

We're documenting all BSON object types as `array|object` (i.e. `A` in `zend_parse_parameters()`). We do plan on having BSON classes defined, and users should be able to provide associative arrays, `stdClass` instances, or `BSON\Object` (name is still tentative) as needed.

> I should create a whole new class and transform it on the MongoDB\Query\Query with the subsequent overhead?

I made a basic benchmark for Query object construction in [this gist](https://gist.github.com/jmikola/fe2a333e5d5da4ddfbe7). This only compares creation of the Query constructor arguments (i.e. assigning basic PHP variables) with and without the actual constructor call, and it appears that the constructor doubles the time per iteration. I'll likely revise this later to test a mutable Query builder class with and without a method that yields our immutable Query object, but I think overhead will be a significant concern.

> The root of the problem is the immutability of MongoDB\Query\Query the current implementation requires to convert a userland Query object into a MongoDB\Query\Query adding overhead and complexity.

If we were implementing the current driver's API atop what we have here (i.e. [MongoCursor](http://php.net/manual/en/class.mongocursor.php)), MongoCollection's `find()` would construct a "userland" MongoCursor class with just the query selector/projection arguments and additional options (e.g. limit, skip) would be set by their respective methods. When it's time to start iterating, the MongoCursor would then use its internal variables to create a Query object for `executeQuery()` -- all of which could take place in a `getIterator()` method if this MongoCursor implemented IteratorAggregate.

In the case above, the methods to set options and flags of the cursor are specific to our decision to replicate MongoCursor's API. Now, suppose we were building a fluent API for querying, akin to Doctrine MongoDB's [Builder class](https://github.com/doctrine/mongodb/blob/a226fce76171d9b22bfff05a9c32955022e46b2a/lib/Doctrine/MongoDB/Query/Builder.php). The internal methods we made for MongoCursor no longer apply, since MongoCursor doesn't have an API for mutating the `$query` modifier; however, this new Builder class does want to modify that `$query` modifier because we have methods for various query operators (e.g. `in()`, `notEqualTo()`).

The Query value objects we're defining is the lowest common denominator of what each implementation would need. This is one level above having `Manager::executeQuery()` take the actual fields in the `OP_QUERY` wire protocol message, but we wanted a class for type-hinting and to keep `executeQuery()`'s argument list sane.

As an immutable value object, I see no reason that this would need to be extended. But as a general rule, we also want to keep as many classes `final` as possible while prototyping until we come across a good reason to remove the restriction. As I mentioned above, we can always immediately remove `final` without breaking BC, but we can't do the opposite.

> Why accept object? In PHP no one use stdClass as value objects (and if any do it, should not) this duality disables the option of use the type hinting and not is very clean.

stdClass may not be used as value objects, but MongoDB users have at times had to cast arrays to objects to ensure data is serialized as BSON objects instead of arrays. The best example of this is attempting to set a field to an empty object instead of an empty array. `['$set' => ['x' => (object)[]]]` must be used instead of `['$set' => ['x' => []]]`.

While userland type-hinting cannot be used here, the C extension does use `zend_parse_parameters()`'s `A` flag to assert the argument type with each method call. In PHP userland, the alternative is to add an `if` statement to throw the appropriate exception to the argument is not an array or object. That's what I've been doing in the Bulk API work in [mongo-php-fluent](https://github.com/jmikola/mongo-php-fluent), and while it does add an extra couple of LOC, I wager the overhead is still slim.

We're making a point to accept `array|object` in places where "documents" are expected. This is also thinking ahead for when we introduce a BsonObject class (practically no different than stdClass for ensuring serialization to a BSON object type). In the current driver, we are inconsistent in some places about requiring PHP arrays when we really should expect a BSON object.

> The overhead problem comes from `Whatever\Query` to `MongoDB\Query\Query`

I don't understand your argument here. Are you hoping to pass a `Whatever\Query` userland class to `Manager::executeQuery()`? Our intention is that users are building APIs on top of this extension, not extending it (again: composition over inheritance). Still, if this hypothetical `Whatever` library has a Query class that is intended to work with `Manager::executeQuery()` in the core extension, it could have a factory method that creates the requisite `MongoDB\Query\Query` value object.

In light of https://gist.github.com/jmikola/fe2a333e5d5da4ddfbe7, I don't agree that constructing a `MongoDB\Query\Query` instance is significant overhead.

> This not applies when we are passing the var as an argument, in both cases the $query is an array, the content never will be splited in several arrays and passed as parameter to another function.

I don't understand what you mean by this statement. My argument was that PHP itself gives us no way to infer if an array (either empty or numerically sequenced) should be serialized into a BSON object or array type. Contrast this with Python, where we have actual list and dict types that are not ambiguous at all.

In the case of Query's constructor, we do know that `$query` should always be document (per the [wire protocol](http://docs.mongodb.org/meta-driver/latest/legacy/mongodb-wire-protocol/#op-query)); however, type-hinting to require a PHP array is an artificial limit -- stdClass and the future BsonObject class we hope to create are also valid representations of a document, and users should be allowed to use them anywhere a document argument is expected.

To be fair, supporting PHP arrays is the concession we made for a friendly API -- their ambiguous nature makes them ideal for neither BSON arrays or objects, but we support them anyway because they are convenient for users.

By allowing arrays and objects, we're also setting (or at least suggesting) an example for userland libraries to follow. This is what we'll do for the userland PHP libs developed atop this driver (e.g. a compatibility library providing the 1.5.x driver API, our [Bulk API](https://github.com/jmikola/mongo-php-fluent/pull/1), etc.). I'd also plan to do the same for Doctrine, but third-party libraries are free to make their own decisions.

> Remove this duality will make too a boost of performance because you dont need to check for an array or a object (for sure zend_parse_parameters will make it ultrafast but need check for the two types).

Benchmarked: https://gist.github.com/jmikola/4e0db2f7499909da33f6

Apart from the `if` statement, the functions do nothing more than return immediately -- and the manual type check adds ~2 microseconds of additional processing time. If we were adding this logic to critical code paths that execute many times in succession (e.g. a BSON utility function that would be called repeatedly while encoding a single PHP value), I could see this being a concern -- but not as-is.

> Make a requirement the usage of a BSON object instead a plain array will be add complexity and performance penalty.

This is not a requirement, as we're accepting both arrays _and_ objects. BsonObject is further down the line, but my immediate concern was allowing arrays and stdClass instances, which are the result of casting arrays as objects.

@bjori: I believe I made all of the changes discussed apart from:

> `query->batch_size = Z_LVAL_PP(data);`
> What if its not an integer?

How do you think we should handle this? I'm under the impression that accessing the zval as a long is going to produce the same result as zpp would for `MongoCursor::batchSize()`. Am I mistaken?

Yes, both of the write error tests fail due to a segfault in `_zend_mm_free_int`:
- manager-executeWriteBatch-002.phpt
- manager-executeWriteBatch-003.phpt

I pasted the backtrace in IRC yesterday: http://pastebin.com/FVEWyZdv

Closing this for now. If we come up with a work-around in the future we can revisit this.

See #19 instead.
Definitely a typo. Thanks!

Tests are green once more!

> Also, it helps a lot if you only include the specific commit for the ticket, not all your previous Pull Requests.

This was based on his other PR and he mentioned the dependency in the original post. It's nothing we haven't already done with 1.x development when we had inter-related PRs with a dependent merge order. Were #48 to be merged, this would get rebased and factor down to the single commit.

I split off the `config.m4` change into #55 and left this PR for PHPC-316 (despite its branch name) since we had relevant comments above. We can revisit this when the Windows build environment is ready.
@bjori: I'll wait for Travis to report green, but I believe this has a LGTM from https://github.com/10gen-labs/mongo-php-driver-prototype/pull/47#issuecomment-117277615.
Travis looks good. This will need a test for sorting on `{ "0": 1 }` and `{ "0": 1, "1": 1 }` to test for proper serialization, though.

This is currently waiting on [CDRIVER-731](https://jira.mongodb.org/browse/CDRIVER-731) and possibly https://github.com/mongodb/mongo-c-driver/pull/246. As-is, the SASL mutex functions generate extra trace output that we can't capture, which causes spurious test failures.

Updated commit to test for `{ "0" : 1 }`, which was all that's really needed. We can verify that the serialization is correct through Query's debug handler.

Additionally, 3.0.x seems to ignore the `$orderby` value if it's not an object. Testing that the documents come back in an order other than their natural (inserted) order helps to test that the server is actually taking our `$orderby` value into account.

@bjori: I cleaned up the cases where I replaced `(%d)` expectations with hard-coded numbers, but I wasn't about to do a global search-and-replace in this PR. I didn't recall any discussion about it. Before this patch, the behavior I observed was that `getServers()` returns Server objects based on the hosts inferred from the URI itself. Those will have an unknown state and it's also possible that their hints won't be usable later on. I think users might be more baffled by the fact that we'd create Server objects for them that may not be usable.

This is distinct from the situation where we might return a Server for a replica set node that ends up being removed from the set (or shut down) before the user attempts to execute an operation on it directly. At least in that case, the Server object did have some known state and an isMaster record.

@bjori: To quote that ticket:

> This is mainly because Manager construction is lazy and Manager::getServers() would return an empy array before initialization time.

At some point, this must have changed. `intern->client->topology->description.servers` might have been an empty set before, but it currently consists of one or more unknown server structs.

> As an aside, such a server selection should be possible to implement in userland given a ReadPreference and manually calling Manager::getServers() and sorting through the info (i.e. isMaster results) and latency for all servers; however, that would require a userland implementation to kickstart SDAM with a ping if the collection of servers was empty.

I suppose this PR is essentially adding that SDAM kickstart process we'd need to implement a userland selection process.

> If getServers() now does half of this, does it then make sense to remove selectServer() The $readPreference argument could be merged to getServers()?

There's benefit in `selectServer()` returning a single Server and raising exceptions when server selection fails. That API was ideal for the needs of PHPLIB.

I do see how `getServers()` could be employed for userland server selection (e.g. with a custom round-robin algorithm), irrespective of whether the extension method took a read preference. That said, I see it more as a diagnostic tool, akin to `getConnections()` in the legacy driver. If we made it more like `selectServer()`, then there'd be the question of whether failing to find any Server(s) would throw or simply return an empty array.

Per discussion in IRC, I've revised [PHPC-361](https://jira.mongodb.org/browse/PHPC-361) to state that `getServers()` should be changed to merely filter out servers in unknown states instead of performing full discovery. This keeps the method passive and removes functional overlap with `selectServer()`.

I'll revise this PR after the 1.0.0-alpha release.

review_comments.body: Other than InsertBatch telling us that the operations are inserts (by its class name), I don't see why we shouldn't just pass in an array of operations. This would mean we'd have specific methods like `executeInsert()`, which I think is fine. In the C code, it means there's no need to check the class and then branch off internally to the appropriate write method in libmongoc. Also, being able to pass an array of operations (e.g. documents to insert or the update arguments) in one shot addresses @derickr's concern about having a simple interface.
Renamed Mongolizable to BsonSerializable. This mimics JsonSerializable and I don't see the harm in referring to BSON if we're already going to do it in the type mappings elsewhere.

Alternatively, this could be a single argument with an array of _our own_ concept query options:
- query document (where we store [query modifiers](http://docs.mongodb.org/manual/reference/operator/query-modifier/))
- selector document
- flags
- limit
- skip

I'm against the original design, which had the selector, flags, limit, and skip options _within_ the query document, as that requires C code to pluck out options before we can send anything to libmongoc. Also, there is a hypothetical situation if the server added a `$limit` query modifier which was different than the current concept of a limit. Since the server does document valid query modifiers, I don't think we should attempt to put other fields inside that document at this time.

All that said, I would support having Query's constructor take a single array of options instead of separate arguments, as I know having a constructors with many args (many of which are optional in their own right) is asking for trouble down the line if we need to change the API.

Read preferences are strings, so I don't think the base driver needs to enforce constants. That is easily maintained in PHP userland, unless we need to throw exceptions for unrecognized read preferences?
Previously, this was QueryResult. I'm not sure what the relation of that class would be to the result of a command, which would also be iterable (i.e. Traversable in PHP) and possibly a cursor.
To that end, shouldn't WriteOptions and possible WriteConcern also have their own class?
That makes sense and I believe we talked about that, too. It wasn't clear from the `foreach` that we'd rely on IteratorAggregate :)
These factory methods may not even be necessary, as the userland layer can simply interpret the command response and construct the cursors outright.

Is this intended to be comparable to MongoClient's constructor? If so, wouldn't we need a DSN _and_ connection options?

ReadPreference and WriteOptions classes need to be defined. Commands don't always require a ReadPreference, so I'm not sure how best to handle this. Additionally, commands and queries alike probably need general options to handle socket timeouts (something I imagine was intended to be handled with WriteOptions). Perhaps we need a ClientOptions argument, too?
This is likely the place to apply the white list of commands that must be sent to a primary.
NoPrimaryAvailable and NoServerMatchingReadPreference need to be defined.
This is essentially everything that makes up an `OP_QUERY` (i.e. everything necessary to create a cursor on the server).

The "first batch" handling for a command cursor may still apply for query cursors, as it's comparable to the documents returned in the first `OP_REPLY` after `OP_QUERY`.

As discussed in video chat, the constructor cannot take a CommandResult directly, since that leaves us with now way to create command cursors from parallelCollectionScan result documents. We agreed to remove this factory method completely.

We discussed that both arguments should be removed, and we're be swapping the constructor with `fromDsn()`, since DSN-based construction is the default convention. Servers can be manually constructed with their own options, and we'll have a general factory method to create a Manager with a specific collection of servers.

This and Query do not have getter methods, since I assume their data will be accessed internally. Users shouldn't have any reason to read these objects after creating them.

I went back to using an array in lieu of WriteOptions class, since the set of options is really not a value object. The write options array for the three single-operation convenience methods is comparable to the options used in constructing the WriteBatch classes, except the WriteBatch classes would require an `ordered` option as well (akin to what we currently have in MongoWriteBatch).

Write options are no longer specified here, since they're provided when the WriteBatch is constructed. That may be a problem if we need to implement an API where write options can be provided after a batch is ready to go, so I can revert to what we had earlier if necessary.

I'm all for `isOk()` on the Result object that does `! empty($data['ok'])` internally.

Don't we have to manually run other things in `.travis.scripts` to set up our local environments? We can discuss a better way to deal with this, but I'm also expecting that our MongoDB Orchestration library will be a separate thing to install, too -- so we should come up with a general, happy solution.

I didn't realize these were case-insensitive, but that is indeed awkward. I'll replace with case-sensitive comparisons. Why was `zend_binary_strcasecmp()` being used in the write command functions of our current driver? (that's the code I was referencing here).
I believe `ZEND_STRS` is in order, since `ZEND_STRL()` is the same as `strlen()`. `key_len` here includes the null byte.
I'm using the same terminology in the CRUD API spec. I'll bring this point up with them.

The one-liner long assignments sounds good (since the values are initially zero and will be set to zero again if the options are missing). For the `array|object`, we need the extra logic, though. We can do one of two things:
- Use `php_array_fetch*_array`, which means we can't support objects since the function returns a null pointer if it's not an array type
- Fetch a generic zval, raise an error if it's not an `array|object`, explicitly convert to an array and merge. We don't want to let users pass scalars for such options, as we could end up merging weird stuff (e.g. `[ 5 ]`).

I'm opting for the second choice.
I believe I mentioned this in IRC, but there's no plans to change the terminology. Shouldn't really be much of an issue here, since we're not forcing users to write out the name of this option.

I explained the reasoning behind this here in https://github.com/bjori/phongo/pull/12#discussion_r16569526, which is now hidden in the PR :)

One question I have for you is how would we like to throw exceptions in these functions. The `php_error_docref()` call for `filter` validation up top is fine (it's more of an assertion), but for these options I'd certainly like to throw exceptions.

I was under the impression that we wanted to support `array|object` wherever BSON documents are allowed. This means we can be strict about arrays for `$options` arguments on PHP methods, but we should be flexible for anything that gets serialized to a BSON document.

Dumb example, but let's say you had documents fields named `0` and `1` and wanted to sort by `{ "0": 1, "1": -1 }`. Unless we allow an object, PHP is going to screw us and we'll end up serializing `$orderby` as a BSON array. I'm not sure if the server actually allows both, since it's just a type field difference, but I think it's just easier to keep our code flexible.

> Can zquery not be initialized as php_array_fetchc(options, "modifiers")? Even skipping the existsc()?

`options` might not even exist (it's an optional Query constructor arg), so we still need to initialize `zquery`.

I wasn't aware that the server team planned to require `$query` in the future. I don't see the harm in always using it, though. It helps keep our query documents consistent regardless of whether modifiers are used.
As discussed in IRC, I'll create a `writeexception_t` struct and move this over to there.
https://jira.mongodb.org/browse/PHP-1232
Too much indentation here.
Too much indentation here.
![](http://img.pandawhale.com/94289-I-did-not-know-that-gif-Rob-Lo-AvqX.gif)

I changed this to omit `w` if it's equal to `MONGOC_WRITE_CONCERN_W_DEFAULT`. We'll still print `wtag`, `"majority"`, or the numeric value for all other cases.

I'd like to do the same for `journal` and `fsync`, but that depends on mongodb/mongo-c-driver#194 being merged. As for `wtimeout`, 0 is considered the empty value for that. Ultimately, I think we need support for `null` arguments to WriteConcern or to simply take an `$options` array and be done with it. One argument is that we're locking ourselves into having an argument for `fsync`, which we already know is deprecated.
I think you missed this when adding `(char *)""` for the second arg.
This should be fine provided we don't compile with `-Wcast-qual`.
If these should be realigned, I can do so in a subsequent commit.

I originally thought of getting rid of this declaration and just passing the return value directly below. I then realized that `php_phongo_read_preference_to_zval()` doesn't actually check that this is a valid pointer, and `phongo_read_preference_from_zval()` may return `NULL`. Should we add a sanity check here?

Anything is possible.

![](http://i.giphy.com/yidUzuMf6DH8cz09zO.gif)
Let's save that before the final release in case we introduce more changes.
This method was removed. Killing of cursors when they go out of scope will be implemented in [PHPC-225](https://jira.mongodb.org/browse/PHPC-225).

This test wasn't relevant anymore, since we're no longer implementing Iterator.

That said, I don't understand why the cursor was dumped on the 10th iteration and we expected `firstBatch` to be:

```
array(1) {
  ["username"]=>
  string(16) "abernathy.audrey"
}
```
The batchSize methods were removed, as we no longer allow this to be changed during iteration (we simply initialize it based on the Query's option). `isDead()` can be tested elsewhere.
Tests for kill on destruct are now added.

The reason I didn't think it was necessary was that we already call `php_phongo_cursor_free_current()` at the top of this function. Thereafter, the `cursor->visitor_data` is only populated in two possible places:
- `bson_iter_next()` on `first_batch_iter` succeeded, and the element was a document. `bson_to_zval()` is invoked to populate `cursor->visitor_data` and we return immediately.
- `mongoc_cursor_next()` returned successfully and sets the `doc` pointer. We then call `bson_to_zval()` to populate `cursor->visitor_data`.

In the latter case (cursor iteration), this line of code is the `else` condition (i.e. cursor iteration didn't have a next document). I don't see any point where `cursor->visitor_data` could have been populated.

Since this only frees `cursor->visitor_data.zchild` if it's not null, was there a specific reason to move it up? I've no objection if it was just for style points, but I'm curious if there was another reason.
Since we can rewind a command cursor multiple times to iterate through the first batch (before we trigger a getmore), wouldn't this invite a memory leak?
This should be PHPC and omit the leading zero.
I suggested removing this because, after simplifying our iteration handlers, it would only be used in the Cursor's debug handler.

Is this `php_phongo_cursor_free_current()` call actually necessary? `php_phongo_cursor_free()` already calls `php_phongo_cursor_free_current()`, and that will be invoked by `php_phongo_cursor_free_object()` when the zval is destroyed.

Since the cursor is initialized to point to its first result, the rewind handler really need not do anything other than load the current element. `cursor_it->current` is already initialized to zero when allocating the structure. 

I actually think we should not reset `cursor_it->current` to zero here, as rewinding should be a NOP. Alternatively, we could be more aggressive and throw an exception if `cursor_it->current` is greater than zero (to notify users that they shouldn't be rewinding after they've started iteration).

Whatever we decide to do, we can easily test by wrapping our Cursor in an IteratorIterator, which allows us to trigger the rewind handler by calling `rewind()` in userland.
@derickr: Take note that I'm removing "firstBatch" and "is_command_cursor" from the Cursor object's debug output. If this is merged, I will create HHVM tickets for you.

Ah, I forgot about [PHPC-230](https://jira.mongodb.org/browse/PHPC-230). This should certainly fix it, though, since we are now relying on the final return statement after the common `phongo_cursor_init()` below.
If the `zval_ptr_dtor((zval**)&cursor_it->intern.data);` below destroys the last reference to the zval, wouldn't its "free_object" handler get invoked?

But the "free_object" handler already calls `php_phongo_cursor_free_current()`. So it would either implicitly be invoked by us dtor-ing the zval here (if it's the last reference) or later on (if there is some other reference). And if there was another reference, there's probably no need to free the current element. If a second iterator is created for the Cursor (i.e. `php_phongo_cursor_t` struct), then its own rewind would free the current element anyway, but that's a side effect of two PHP iterators sharing the same Cursor.

I don't think so. `cursor_it->current` is zero from "get_iterator" allocating the `php_phongo_cursor_iterator` struct. The "move_forward" handler isn't called until we advance to the element beyond the first, since only "rewind" would be called (obviously after "get_iterator") when iterating through the first element in a `foreach`.

I have two more tests I can add to the PR tomorrow. Basically, I want to iterate through the Cursor with a `foreach` and call `rewind()` at each iteration and assert that it's a NOP (both for altering the current element _and_ the index). Since we can't very well rewind earlier into the BSON buffer (especially after a getmore overwrites a previous batch), I'd just like to test that rewinding doesn't change the value or key progression.
For PHPC-275: this conditional and the preceding `(!obj_data)` conditional (when `zend_call_method()` fails) are the relevant changes for the `bson-encode_error-002.phpt` test case.

For PHPC-274: this swap of `php_phongo_persistable_ce` to `php_phongo_serializable_ce` is the relevant change for satisfying the non-embedded test cases in `bson-encode-002.phpt` (the embedded test cases already passed before this).
For PHPC-274: since we swapped the `instanceof` check above, we still want to respect the `PHONGO_BSON_ADD_ODS` flag, so this conditional has been added.
This should be an UnexpectedValueException.
This should also be an UnexpectedValueException.

Instead of returning here and after an exception below, we should break and then change the `if (ht_data && ht_data->nApplyCount > 1)` conditional later to also return if `ht_data` is `NULL`. Additionally, ensure we initialize `ht_data` to `NULL` at the top of this function.

I changed the test to use incrementing values for `$wtimeout` to make the test diffs easier to follow (on failure).

We're also adding two new tests here for setting `$journal` but not `$fsync`.
https://github.com/10gen-labs/mongo-php-driver-prototype/pull/43
https://github.com/10gen-labs/mongo-php-driver-prototype/pull/43
I assume it was search/replace or retcon-ing old release logs.

The projection and query document (i.e. what we merge modifiers into above) didn't need this treatment since they are top-level documents and you encode them as such later on. Sort was the unique case where it gets stuffed in an `$orderby` field and could be encoded as an array inadvertently.

I do mean to split these changes up into separate commits, but the `convert_to_array_ex()` deletions here and for modifiers are basically just removing dead code.

I realized that `MONGOC_ENABLE_SASL` was also missing when we configured without SASL (same issue that you brought up with `MONGOC_HAVE_SASL_CLIENT_DONE`). Relevant libmongoc changes are https://github.com/mongodb/mongo-c-driver/commit/c3c14f431864c82f670581c0e380cef9047cfb96.
I'm passing `NULL` here because we don't actually check `eof` until the second call, which your original do/while loop was accomplishing.
`MAKE_STD_ZVAL(state.zchild)` is always called before we venture into `bson_to_zval()`, which is why we free. This shouldn't depend on whether we called `array_init()` within `bson_to_zval()`.
Noted. I pulled this right from the ticket, but I did see you made those global functions for a reason :)

I avoided placing the `zval_ptr_dtor()` within `bson_to_zval()` because every calling context (excluding the `toArray()` function, which I address in this PR) was already freeing the zval on its own. Since this function expects the zval to already be allocated, the calling contexts are able to make that decision.

commit_comments.body: That doesn't look right. The array() should end after "\r".

review_comments.body: Do we really want to have this as both array _and_ object again?
Sadly, you can't do this. On a 32bit platform (and Windows), $cursorID _has_ to be a MongoInt64 object.
Wouldn't it make more sense to just pass in a document that was returned from the "runCommand" method (+ $server)? Is there a need to split it up into cursorId and firstBatch yourself?
I agree, don't add this if it's not necessary... but, alternatively the constructor could just accept Server and CommandResult instead?
I would probably suggest calling this getResponseDocument() — it's more descriptive as to what it does. Right now, it could be interpreted as some pre-processed response.
What is it extending ServerResult for?
Technically the DSN should be able to include all connection options, but I would prefer it being a second (array) argument too.
If that's the case, we need to define the bitfields constants for all the flags. Or alternatively, we can make query flags an array with the options in there.
Yeah, that's pretty much what firstBatch would mean for OP_QUERY results.
If we do export this, it should always return a MongoInt64 object.
What does this do?
I thought we previous discussed just to have a "getServerInfo" method instead of all those getters?
And this needs the insert, update and delete methods too. With $namespace being our MongoDB\Namespace value object.
There is sometimes more than one message. wnote, jnote, msg, etc.
What are we using this for?

This is perhaps quite limited as you never know what the server adds in future versions. Perhaps it should be a generic method to ask for server result stuff? (And not only for delete, also for insert and update).
It should also return a list of all the new _id fields -- one per document.
`$namespace` should be `\MongoDB\Namespace $namespace`

After reading the `cursor-iterator_handlers-001.phpt` testcase, I think we have to throw an exception in `rewind()` if the cursor has been iterated over, or in the middle of iteration.
Repeated calls to `rewind()` without `next()` in between is fine (although doesn't make a lot of sense), but after iteration has started a call to `rewind()` really has to throw `OutOfBoundsException`.

It is really confusing if calling `rewind()` is somewhat of a `NOOP` and you can continue stepping through some parts of it.

```
rewind($cursor); $first = current($cursor); next($cursor);
rewind($cursor); $firstAgain = current($cursor);
```

```
$first must be == $firstAgain
```

And since cannot do that without re-executing the query, which we clearly don't want to do -- I think we must throw an exception.

You don't need to run ./autogen.sh for phongo, we generate the correct config files -- that is only necessary following the [HHVM instructions](https://github.com/mongodb/mongo-hhvm-driver#from-source).
And in fact, there is no ./autogen.sh script for the driver itself :)

Compiling the mongo-php-driver from source only requires:

``` shell
git clone git@github.com:mongodb/mongo-php-driver.git -b master mongo
cd mongo
git submodule init
git submodule update
phpize
./configure
make
sudo make install
```

$limit, $skip order will forever require quick documentation lookup.
I foresee $queryFields becoming part of a $queryDocument in the near future, on the same level as $orderyBy

I think having these as separate arguments will is indeed asking for problems down the line.
I would prefer an array of "our own" query options so we do not tie us into a dedicated implementation detail on how the current query and opcode wire protocol works.

I actually think it was a bad call to make it an array.
It should be ReadPreference class. Validating this array will be a source of a mess otherwise.
Typehinting on ReadPreferences solves that completely.

I was thinking an intermediate step from query execution to the actual cursor.
I can imagine if a query becomes a command in the future the return value of that would be a cursor document, along with maybe some statistics such as execution time and timestamp of the last entry in the oplog so a user can decide to discard the results and try another secondary instead or whatever the future may hold.

QueryResult would implement IteratorAggregate and return a Cursor which would only be that, a iterable cursor.

Having a classname makes it easier and cleaner to validate the actual operations.
Having to validate enormous array all the time is both complex and not something you want to have multiple branches of in one method.

Allow individual classes to provide their own validation and then simply be typehinted simplifies the entire chain of events and allows us to keep small pieces of selfcontained code.

Having an executeInsert(array($document1, $document2)); is begging for validation issues and "whops, I did executeInsert($document)"

This was relatively intentional.
If w=MONGOC_WRITE_CONCERN_W_DEFAULT, and fsync and j aren't specifcally provided, then there is no writeConcern.
In pre-2.6 it means that getLastError will be called, with no arguments, and the server defaults applied.
In 2.6+ it means no writeConcern document provided with the write, and the server defaults applied

issue_comments.body:
I just come back from NYC, now i have regular internet access :dancers: 

@jmikola i understand that is is a minimal layer but this layer must enable to the following developers extend it easily.

How I can make implement in userland my proposed query class? I cannot read/change the query properties at all, I should create a whole new class and transform it on the `MongoDB\Query\Query` with the subsequent overhead? I understand that is a representation of the parameters of the OP_QUERY message but let to the userland use it.

About the final classes I understand the problem (especially the $ vars) but maybe is que case of `MongoDB\Query\Query` can be one of this candidates for remove the final and expose this properties as protected. Query is a very basic concept and the properties too.

The root of the problem is the immutability of `MongoDB\Query\Query` the current implementation  requires to convert a userland Query object into a `MongoDB\Query\Query` adding overhead and complexity.

I see clearly this BSON object but not at Query class, more as as a representation of the message at the final stage before execution, at this point this will be add many overhead and add complexity in the userland. 

Why accept object? In PHP no one use stdClass as value objects (and if any do it, should not)  this duality disables the option of use the type hinting and not is very clean.

Thanks for head my humble opinion.

The overhead problem comes from `Whatever\Query` to `MongoDB\Query\Query` due to cannot extend it, have setters or a construct not makes the diference, i think. 

About the immutability you are limiting the userland because in all cases not apply a mutable object, but as you say the final can be removed without break the BC.

> stdClass may not be used as value objects, but MongoDB users have at times had to cast arrays to objects to ensure data is serialized as BSON objects instead of arrays. The best example of this is attempting to set a field to an empty object instead of an empty array. ['$set' => ['x' => (object)[]]] must be used instead of ['$set' => ['x' => []]].

This not applies when we are passing the var as an argument, in both cases the $query is an array, the content never will be splited in several arrays and passed as parameter to another function.

Remove this duality will make too a boost of performance because you dont need to check for an array or a object (for sure `zend_parse_parameters`will make it ultrafast but need check for the two types).

Make a requirement the usage of a BSON object instead a plain array will be add complexity and performance penalty. BSON object is a good idea but in the more deep clases like Server or Manager.

@jmikola When compiling (for instance) PHP 5.6.31, this CHECK_FUNC_IN_HEADER evaluates as false. It adds a

`#DEFINE HAVE_SOCKLEN_T 0`

to main/config.w32.h, which is a redefinition of the

`#DEFINE HAVE_SOCKLEN_T 1`

that is already there:
https://github.com/php/php-src/blob/PHP-5.6.31/win32/build/config.w32.h.in#L155

I did not check in PHP master yet, but I guess the problem is the same.

Checked with PHP 7.1. The same problem:

```
C:\php-sdk\php71dev\main\../main/config.w32.h(674): warning C4005: 'HAVE_SOCKLEN_T': macro redefinition (compiling source file Zend\zend_compile.c)
C:\php-sdk\php71dev\main\../main/config.w32.h(146): note: see previous definition of 'HAVE_SOCKLEN_T' (compiling source file Zend\zend_compile.c)
```

This is now breaking PHP 7.2 builds on Travis, because Travis CI is using PHP 7.2.0beta3.
See failing Doctrine build here: https://travis-ci.org/doctrine/data-fixtures/jobs/273067384
